content.webTitle: Corbyn victory may lead to further leadership challenge, says ally

fields.headline: Corbyn victory may lead to further leadership challenge, says ally
fields.bodyText: Jeremy Corbyn’s supporters should brace themselves for the possibility of a new challenge against him even if he wins Labour’s leadership contest this weekend, according to the chair of the influential social movement set up to back him. Momentum’s founder, Jon Lansman, was speaking on Tuesday night to volunteers taking part in phone canvassing as the leadership contest entered its final hours, telling them that their services would be needed in a general election but also potentially to fend off a fresh leadership challenge from inside Labour. Corbyn and the shadow chancellor, John McDonnell, later addressed hundreds of volunteers at the headquarters of the Unite trade union as their campaign sought to make 10,000 calls to Labour members and supporters on a “super Tuesday” of campaigning. While Corbyn gave little away about his view of proceedings at Tuesday’s meeting of the party’s national executive committee – which failed to reach a consensus over how to persuade MPs to return to his frontbench – Lansman also told volunteers that there had been “some good, some not so good” snippets of news from the NEC. Lansman didn’t elaborate but one item of agreement to come out of the NEC was that it would have two new members with full voting rights from the Scottish and Welsh executives. Corbyn’s allies had wanted the Scottish and Welsh representatives on the NEC to be voted on to it by members. In a meeting that lasted more than eight hours, the Labour leader also refused to sign up to plans put forward by his deputy, Tom Watson, under which Labour politicians would be allowed to vote for the shadow cabinet. McDonnell told volunteers manning the phone banks at the Unite offices that they should be “careful” about the outcome of the leadership contest on Saturday. “I think it’s going to be tough … to meet the levels that we got last year and I say that because they have thrown everything against us,” he added. He added that there would be a call for unity after Corbyn won. “We have already got members of the PLP [parliamentary Labour party] coming back, which is great. And what is wonderful is that the new generation is coming forward, which is what Jeremy is all about.” Lansman also sought to manage expectations, adding: “We don’t know what Saturday’s result will be but let me reassure you we have booked a party.”
